question.title: How do i connect a java app to connect to a DBISAM database (CRUD functionalities)
question.body:
I am trying to create a Java application that connects to a DBISAM database. My goal is to perform standard CRUD operations (Create, Read, Update, Delete).

I have tried the following approaches:

  1. ZappySys DSN / JDBC Bridge
  2. ODBC connection using Easysoft drivers
  3. Various JDBC bridge connectors provided by ZappySys

However, none of these approaches worked. I was unable to:

  • Establish a connection to the DBISAM database
  • Create a database programmatically
  • Execute SQL queries

Here is an example of what I tried with ZappySys JDBC Bridge:

package com.school.dbisamconnectionexample;

import java.sql.*;


public class DBISAMConnectionExample {    
    
    private static final String JDBC_URL = "jdbc:odbc:YOUR_DSN_NAME";  // e.g., jdbc:odbc:MyDBISAMDB
    private static final String USER = "";  // Usually empty for DBISAM unless configured
    private static final String PASSWORD = "";  // Usually empty
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        Connection conn = null;
        Statement stmt = null;
        ResultSet rs = null;
    
           try {
            // Load the JDBC-ODBC driver (only needed for older Java; auto-loaded in Java 6+)
            Class.forName("sun.jdbc.odbc.JdbcOdbcDriver");
            // Establish connection
            conn = DriverManager.getConnection(JDBC_URL, USER, PASSWORD);
            System.out.println("Connected to DBISAM database.");
            // Create a statement and execute a query (adjust table/query as needed)
            stmt = conn.createStatement();
            rs = stmt.executeQuery("SELECT * FROM YourTableName");  // DBISAM uses SQL-like syntax
            // Process results
            while (rs.next()) {
                // Assuming a column named 'ID' and 'Name'
                int id = rs.getInt("ID");
                String name = rs.getString("Name");
                System.out.println("ID: " + id + ", Name: " + name);
            }
        } catch (ClassNotFoundException e) {
            System.err.println("JDBC-ODBC Driver not found: " + e.getMessage());
        } catch (SQLException e) {
            System.err.println("Database error: " + e.getMessage());
        } finally {
            // Clean up resources
            try {
                if (rs != null) rs.close();
                if (stmt != null) stmt.close();
                if (conn != null) conn.close();
            } catch (SQLException e) {
                System.err.println("Error closing resources: " + e.getMessage());
            }
        }
    }
}

question_comments.body: As mentioned by @ElliottFrisch the sun.jdbc.odbc.JdbcOdbcDriver driver was removed in Java 8 on 2014. The question uses the Maven tag but the pom is missing to understand the dependencies used. Please provide a minimal reproducible example in the question and explain the database vendor, version and drivers used.
The JDBC-ODBC driver was removed in Java 8. What is a DBISAM? Do you mean DB2? DB2 switched from ISAM to VSAM a long time ago. Your question is very confusing.
Please post your pom.xml and how you run this code.
im not sure where to get the exact driver that will work, i tried getting it from elevate software but i was not able to get the coonection right

Please do see the update i made sorry about that, i have been using a lot of methods to get this sorted out. Zappy provided me those code and mentioned it was bound to work with the current code i keep on getting  " JDBC-ODBC Driver not found: sun.jdbc.odbc.JdbcOdbcDriver " i got the driver from
Where do those database files come from? Some other application? If you don't have to maintain compatibility with some legacy application, why not use a popular embedded database like SQLite?

The code shows a SQL Server connection string, not even an ODBC connection string. You can't just use random drivers to connect, you need to find ODBC or JDBC drivers specific to your database product. ZappySys doesn't provide DBISAM drivers. In fact, googling shows that DBISAM is a product by Elevate Software created as a replacement of Borland's Database Engine. You'll have to look at the product's site for drivers. It's so obscure there are only 22 SO questions with that tag
What does that mean, "I was unable to [...]"? Compilation failed? Runtime errors? Everything executed successfully, but the database was not updated?
